abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Child Welfare Reform
            Project in Bulgaria were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Lessons learned included: 1)
            The NGOs become more and more a reliable partner in both the
            design and provision of social services. However, their
            capacity is not always equally well developed across the
            country. Thus, before outsourcing these services to the
            NGOs, thorough assessment of their capacity and
            effectiveness has to be conducted, and if training needs are
            identified, they should be provided with; 2) When new
            institutions are created at both national and local levels,
            a particular attention has to be paid to a clear definition
            of responsibilities between the new ones and the already
            existing one in the institutional landscape, to avoid
            possible institutional clashes that could hamper the reform
            process; 3) The sustained commitment of the local
            authorities (municipalities) is a pre-requisite for the
            successful implementation of the sub-projects in the local
            communities. This commitment has to be built up and secured
            well before their selection as partners in the project
            implementation is done; 4) The up-front acknowledgment of
            the project complexity, in the preparation process, has to
            be accompanied by a realistic implementation timeframe, to
            allow the proper achievement of the project objectives. In
            most of such cases, three year implementation period is not enough.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Child Welfare Reform Project
            protects children's rights in Bulgaria. There are four
            project components. The first provides for technical
            assistance and training for capacity building, management,
            standard setting for the state agency for child protection,
            and for the provision of social services at the local Child
            Protection Department. This component will also support
            monitoring and evaluation of all project activities,
            development and implementation of a management information
            system, and a public awareness campaign to support reform
            implementation. The second component will support the
            Bulgarian government in improving child welfare through
            identifying, financing, monitoring, and evaluating
            sub-projects targeted at preventing abandonment and
            institutionalization of children, leading to the
            de-institutionalization of children in residential care and
            an improved quality of residential care. It establishes
            instead alternative community-based services such as
            community support centers for family counseling, parental
            education, foster care services, staff training, counseling
            services for young offenders, and community development
            activities as well as temporary shelter for young, single
            mothers and their babies, and small group homes. The third
            component focuses on interventions aimed at preventing child
            abandonment in high-risk communities, like the Roma
            community. The last component identifies, finances,
            implements, and monitors sub-projects that target street children.
